passages.text: DG | \(\) 111.20\$ In Line | Target Price/Base Case: \(\) 12\(\) Company Update

DG reported solid 2Q results at \(\) 1.86+9.4\%\(YoY vs. The Street at\) \ \(1.58\) . The full year EPS guide of \(\) 6.05\(at the midpoint is\) 4\%\(above the prior Street outlook. DG stock has essentially been trading sideways since June, and today's results are likely to support the\) 8\%\(option implied move higher based on our first look. Dollar General's turnaround is progressing ahead of schedule, with a\) 2.8\%\(comp ahead of the Street's\) 2.6\%\(and EBIT dollars up\) 8\%\(YoY vs. the\) 6\%\(decline the Street had modeled in. DG is continuing to execute against its back to basics focus, with comps that are hovering around industry growth. Key from here will be addressing reinvestment needs in store wage rate and hours, price positioning, as well as supply chain enhancements needed to sustain the momentum amidst a competitive food retail industry backdrop. From a consumer perspective DG has traditionally served as a trade in option for value seekers, and we see these results as more consistent with that positioning.

2Q results exceeded the Street with gross profit the driver. Sales of \(\) 10.7\(bn up\) 5.1\%\(YoY came in ahead of the Street's\) \ \(10.68bn + 4.6\%\) outlook. Comps of \(2.8\%\) came in ahead of the \(2.6\%\) Street estimate although the two- year stack moderated from a \(4.8\%\) last qtr to a \(3.3\%\) this quarter. Grocery industry growth hovered right around \(3\%\) in the period, so there is still a slight lag to address yet DG's comp is narrowing the gap. We believe the main reason for improving sales is improved in- store execution that is enabling / fostering trade- in for value hungry consumers, yet DG is also expanding its multichannel offering with Uber Eats while building on DoorDash partnership momentum that aids convenience as well. Gross margin of \(31.3\%\) rose 137bps YoY vs. the Street's \(+60bp\) outlook. Drivers included lower shrink, higher inventory mark- ups, and lower inventory damages, partially offset by increased LIFO provision, increased markdowns, and increased distribution costs. SG&A at \(25.8\%\) rose 120bps YoY as well. Incentive comp, repairs and maintenance, and benefits were the primary drivers of de- leverage. EBIT at \(\) 595\(mn rose\) 8\%\(YoY vs. the Street's outlook for\) \ \(516mn\) down \(6\% \(YoY. Margin rate improved 15bps YoY and the Street had modeled 60bps of contraction.

Guidance update: 2H outlook essentially blesses the Street's prior comp and EBIT margin expectations. DG largely updated their full year outlook to reflect 1H outperformance while potentially leaving room for additional 2H25 outperformance in their guide. The EPS guide was increased from the prior \(\) 5.20- \(5.80 to now\) \ \(5.80 - 6.30\) . At the midpoint of \(\) 6.05\(, the guide is 25 cents above the Street's prior outlook of\) \ \(5.80\) . This came with a 28 cent 2Q beat, implying that 2H EPS of \(\) 2.43\(is attainable at the midpoint. The tone of the release suggests that management is pleased with its turnaround progress and that there is ample room to go for further enhancements; however, this suggests that there could be further room for upside relative to the Street's current outlook. On the EBIT margin front, the Street had been modeling 3Q EBIT margin rate up 20bps YoY to\) 3.4\%\(, with 4Q EBIT margin implied up 220bps YoY to\) 5.1\%\(against favorable comparisons. The Street had modeled 2H comps at\) 2.2\%\(previously, a 40bp deceleration vs. 1H25, but a two year stack of around\) 4.5\%\(vs. the 2Q two year stack of\) 3.3\%\(, and 1Q at\) 4.8\%\$

Key Questions for the call: Health of the lower income consumer. Reinvestment needs back into store wage rates and hours. Price gaps and outlook for inflation. Tariff impact if any. New store opening performance updates.

Bottom Line: DG's turnaround efforts are progressing as it looks to regain its status as a leader in every day value food and essentials after a difficult post COVID lull. 2Q marked an important combination of improving comp and margin rate. The key will be sustaining the momentum given that Walmart is growing its Plus effort at a double- digit pace, Amazon is expanding its same day grocery offering with more focus in rural areas, and hard discounters like Aldi are continuing to make in- roads. Ultimately our analysis suggests that there is room for \(15k+\) dollar stores, yet it is important to demonstrate steady comp growth in the \(3\% +\) range, in our view, to demonstrate that ROI can be maintained and improved while adding store units.

Please see the analyst certification and important disclosures on page 3 of this report. Evercore ISI and affiliates do and seek to do business with companies covered in its research reports. Investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. © 2025. Evercore Group L.L.C. All rights reserved.
Earnings multiple at a slight premium to the market.

Potential for Gross margin contraction, as reflected in the CPI- PPI Spread. Wage- freight related inflation. Substantial Competition. Cycling of stimulus. Risks associated with DG are typical of the overall marketplace
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR)
Time of dissemination: August 28 2025 8:07 AM ET

Evercore IS's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:

Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. Coverage Suspended- the rating and target price have been removed pursuant to Evercore ISI policy when Evercore is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving this company and in certain other circumstances. Rating Suspended- Evercore ISI has suspended the rating and target price for this stock because there is not sufficient fundamental basis for determining, or there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints around publishing, a rating or target price. The previous rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this company and should not be relied upon.
Prior to October 10, 2015, the "Coverage Suspended" and "Rating Suspended" categories were included in the category "Suspended."

FINRA requires that members who use a ratings system with terms other than "Buy," "Hold/Neutral" and "Sell" to equate their own ratings to these categories. For this purpose, and in the Evercore ISI ratings distribution below, our Outperform, In Line, and Underperform ratings can be equated to Buy, Hold and Sell, respectively.
